trial_identification.studytitle: Maternal Sleep Health and Foetal Outcomes
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The relationship between maternal sleep health and foetal growth restriction and cardiotocography (CTG) in pregnant women at risk of sleep-disordered breathing versus healthy pregnant women.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Fetal medicine and complications of pregnancy

interventions.interventions: Foetal growth will be observed via ultrasound at 32 and 36 weeks gestation, and at birth. Sleep and foetal heart rate will be monitored with polysomnography and cardiotocography at 38 weeks gestation, for one 8 hour overnight session.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Infant birth weight - A >1/3 fall in birth weight percentile from expected will be considered as slowed late foetal growth.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: blood sample and cord blood for detection of elevated levels of cytokines and markers of oxidative stress.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: between 20-24 weeks gestation Risk factors for sleep disordered breathing, including pre-pregnant obesity (Body Mass Index (BMI) greater than 30kg/m2) and snoring (cases); healthy controls with no history of snoring.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Multiple pregnancy, current pregnancy complicated by pre-eclampsia, previously diagnosed and treated Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA) or other sleep disorder, e.g. narcolepsy, periodic leg movements in sleep (PLMS).

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Bowen Centre Austin Health Studley Road Heidelberg VIC, 3084

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Bowen Centre Austin Health Studley Road Heidelberg , VIC, 3084

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study will investigate the association between sleep-disordered breathing during pregnancy and foetal growth and well-being. It is hypothesised that Obstructive Sleep Apnoea is detrimental to foetal health (acute foetal compromise as evidenced by abnormal cardiotocography (foetal heart rate monitoring) during sleep and impaired foetal growth in late pregnancy).
